rev.comment: /* Coup involvement and Death */ is this [[WP:NOR|original research]]?
rev.diff:
Line 65: Line 65:
== Coup involvement and Death==
== Coup involvement and Death==
â
It is claimed by some that by 1964 he had become convinced that Khrushchev had turned into a liability to the Party, and he was involved in the November 1964 coup that brought [[Leonid Brezhnev]] to power.<ref>Ulam, Adam Bruno. ''Stalin: The Man and His Era''. Boston: Beacon Press, 1987 p. 392 ISBN 0-8070-7005-X</ref> However, Taubman disputes this and Mikoyan was the only member of the Presidium (the name for the Politburo at this time) to defend Khrushchev. Mikoyan, however, did vote to force Khrushchev's retirement (so as in traditional Soviet style to make the vote unanimous). He was the only one of Khrushchev's colleagues to wish him well in his retirement though he never spoke to him again. It is possible to speculate that this was because it would have been politically unwise to do so or because his patience for Khrushchev had gone by then. His decision to send flowers to his funeral in 1971, was perhaps due to guilt, some retained affection for Khrushchev or both.
+
It is claimed by some that by 1964 he had become convinced that Khrushchev had turned into a liability to the Party, and he was involved in the November 1964 coup that brought [[Leonid Brezhnev]] to power.<ref>Ulam, Adam Bruno. ''Stalin: The Man and His Era''. Boston: Beacon Press, 1987 p. 392 ISBN 0-8070-7005-X</ref> However, Taubman disputes this and Mikoyan was the only member of the Presidium (the name for the Politburo at this time) to defend Khrushchev. Mikoyan, however, did vote to force Khrushchev's retirement (so as in traditional Soviet style to make the vote unanimous). He was the only one of Khrushchev's colleagues to wish him well in his retirement, though he never spoke to him again. It is possible to speculate that this was because it would have been politically unwise to do so or because his patience for Khrushchev had gone by then.{{fact}} His decision to send flowers to his funeral in 1971, was perhaps due to guilt, some retained affection for Khrushchev or both.{{fact}}
â
His influence was retained under Brezhnev as Mikoyan was appointed [[President of the Soviet Union|Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet]] from [[1964]] until [[1965]] and then retired. He wrote his memoirs in [[1970]]. He and future [[Premier of the Soviet Union]] [[Alexey Kosygin]], were the only two senior officials in the Soviet government whom stepped down from office voluntarily.
+
His influence was retained under Brezhnev as Mikoyan was appointed [[President of the Soviet Union|Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet]] from [[1964]] until [[1965]] and then retired. He wrote his memoirs in [[1970]]. He and future [[Premier of the Soviet Union]] [[Alexey Kosygin]], were the only two senior officials in the Soviet government who stepped down from office voluntarily.{{fact}}
He died on [[October 21]], [[1978]], at the age of 82 from natural causes and was buried at [[Novodevichy Cemetery]] in Russia.<ref name="GreatSov"/> Mikoyan received a total of six commendations of the [[Order of Lenin]].<ref name="SovArmenian"/> His brother, [[Artem Ivanovich Mikoyan]], was the co-founder and one of the primary designers of the Soviet [[MiG]] military aircraft.
He died on [[October 21]], [[1978]], at the age of 82 from natural causes and was buried at [[Novodevichy Cemetery]] in Russia.<ref name="GreatSov"/> Mikoyan received a total of six commendations of the [[Order of Lenin]].<ref name="SovArmenian"/> His brother, [[Artem Ivanovich Mikoyan]], was the co-founder and one of the primary designers of the Soviet [[MiG]] military aircraft.
